Exercise Description: Lie on your side with legs extended and feet stacked. Place your elbow directly under your shoulder and forearm flat on the ground. Lift your hips off the floor to form a straight line from head to feet. Hold this position, keeping hips square and core braced. Avoid sagging at the hips or rolling forward/backward. Maintain steady breathing throughout the hold.

Lie sideways next to a bench or box and support yourself on your forearm with elbow under shoulder. Place your top leg on the bench with the knee bent at 90 degrees, so the inner thigh rests on the surface. Keep the bottom leg hanging freely beneath. Lift your hips off the floor into a side plank position, forming a straight line from head to knee. Hold the position, keeping hips square and core braced, focusing on adductor engagement.
Perform a glute bridge while squeezing a yoga block or medicine ball between your knees to engage the adductors and stabilise the pelvis. Hold the top position for 3 seconds.

Begin in a bear crawl position with hands under shoulders and knees bent at 90 degrees, hovering a few centimetres off the floor. Hold this iso position with core braced and back flat. From here, lift one hand and tap the opposite knee lightly without shifting hips or letting the torso rotate. Return the hand to the ground and repeat on the other side, alternating taps while maintaining full-body stability.

Begin on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. Extend one arm forward and the opposite leg straight back until both are parallel to the floor. From the extended position, move the arm slowly out to the side in a lateral reach while keeping hips and shoulders square. Return the arm to the forward position, then lower back to start. Maintain core tension and balance throughout.

Stand tall with feet hip-width apart, hands resting on a wall or support for balance if needed. Press through the balls of your feet to rise slowly onto your toes, fully contracting the calves. Pause briefly at the top, then lower under full control to a deep stretch in the heels. Maintain a deliberate, slow tempo throughout, focusing on maximum tension and controlled range of motion.

Lie on your back with one leg extended on the ground and the other raised, looped with a resistance band around the foot. Gently pull the band to bring the raised leg towards you until you feel a stretch in the hamstring. From here, actively push the foot slightly against the band, then relax and pull a little further. Repeat this contract-relax action while keeping the opposite leg flat.

Anchor a resistance band low to the ground and loop it high on the inside of one thigh, stepping out to create tension. Get into an all-fours or half-kneeling position with the band pulling laterally. From here, rock your hips gently back and forth while keeping the banded leg abducted. Move slowly to mobilise and activate the groin, maintaining core stability and upright posture.

Stand with a slight forward lean and keep your core engaged. Perform quick, light foot taps, ensuring your toes stay just off the ground and your ankle remains stiff. The movement should be short and reactive, promoting efficient ground contact and proper sprint foot mechanics.

Start in a half-squat position with feet shoulder-width apart and chest upright. Hinge forward at the hips, place your hands on the floor, and walk them forward step by step until you reach an extended plank position. Hold briefly, then walk your hands back towards your feet and return to the half-squat position. Keep your hips controlled throughout and avoid letting them sag during the plank phase.

Stand facing a wall with hands lightly braced against it for support. Lean forward slightly into a sprinting posture. Drive one knee up towards the chest while keeping the opposite leg extended and foot grounded. Switch legs rhythmically in a straight up-and-down marching pattern, keeping toes dorsiflexed and posture tall. Focus on sharp knee drive and consistent rhythm.

Stand on the balls of your feet, bouncing diagonally to one side off both feet with quick, reactive movements. Keep knees slightly bent and minimal ground contact time. Complete in all four diagonal directions.

Start on your tiptoes with your arms raised above your head, reaching as tall as possible. Engage your core and, in one swift motion, throw all your weight down into the ground, bending your knees and hips to land in a controlled squat position. Your feet should be shoulder-width apart, and your knees should be tracking over your toes. Hold the squat position briefly to ensure control, then return to the starting position and repeat.

Start in an athletic stance. Bound diagonally off one foot, travelling forward and laterally. Land on both feet simultaneously in a low, balanced position, absorbing the force through the hips and holding the landing briefly to show control. Reset and repeat in the opposite direction.

Start tall on your toes with your arms pointed directly upwards overhead. Drop quickly towards the ground and absorb the force in a half-squat. As soon as you stabilise, push off forcefully to the side, leaping laterally to cover distance. Land softly, maintaining control before resetting for the next rep.
Notes: Three sessions per week on single-match weeks.

Exercise Description: Sit on the edge of a bench or box with feet flat on the ground, knees bent at 90 degrees and chest upright. From this static seated position, swing the arms forward and explosively drive through the legs to jump forward as far as possible. Land softly on both feet with knees bent and chest tall. Reset to the bench for each rep. Focus on generating power from a dead start without a counter-movement.

Stand tall with feet hip-width apart and hands by your sides or on your hips. Using only your ankles and calves, perform quick, reactive hops forward and backward over a short distance. Keep your knees mostly straight and land softly on the balls of your feet. Focus on minimal ground contact time and a consistent rhythm. The movement should be springy and controlled, driven through the lower legs without excessive arm swing.

Set a cone as the turning point. Sprint towards it and, without slowing, lean your body slightly into the curve as you run around it. Keep your steps quick and your body angled to maintain speed through the bend. Push off the outside foot to control the curve, then accelerate out of the turn. Focus on rhythm, body lean, and tight foot placement around the cone.

Start in an athletic stance. Perform two consecutive forward bounds, landing softly on each leap with control and balance. Drop your weight backwards on the second landing by dropping the back knee and opening the back hip. Immediately after landing this second leap, transition into a quick, coordinated backpedal over a few yards. Stay low during the transition and maintain chest posture throughout. Focus on explosive forward movement followed by efficient, reactive retreat.

Exercise Name: Goblet Squat with Pulse at Bottom
Exercise Description: Hold a kettlebell in front of your chest in a goblet position. Squat down until hips are below parallel while keeping the chest upright and heels grounded. At the bottom, perform a small pulse by rising a few centimetres up and then lowering back down before standing tall to finish the rep. Maintain posture and core tension throughout, keeping the pulse controlled rather than bouncing.

Position a barbell in the crease of your elbows, holding it securely against your chest with your forearms parallel to the floor. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and your core engaged. Lower yourself into a squat by bending at the hips and knees, keeping your chest upright and elbows slightly forward. Descend until your thighs are parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Stand tall with your arms extended at your sides. Swing both arms forward across your chest in a hugging motion, then open them wide again behind your body. Continue alternating swings in a rhythmic fashion, crossing one arm over the other on each rep. Maintain a relaxed posture and allow your shoulders to move freely. This is a light dynamic movement used to activate the upper body.

Start in a push-up position with your hands under your shoulders. Without bending your elbows, squeeze your shoulder blades together, lowering your chest slightly. Then, push through your hands and round your upper back as your shoulder blades spread apart.

Attach a resistance band to a sturdy anchor at elbow height. Stand sideways to the anchor and hold the band with your outside hand. Keeping your elbow tucked to your side at 90 degrees, rotate your forearm outward against the band’s resistance. Hold the end range briefly before slowly returning to the start. Avoid using your shoulder or upper body to assist; the movement should come from the rotator cuff muscles.

Stand facing a wall in a forward lean with both palms pressed into it at shoulder height. Position one foot forward and one back, knees slightly bent. Actively drive your hands into the wall as hard as possible, bracing through the core and pushing through your back leg. Maintain full tension throughout your body for the duration of the hold, focusing on posture, force intent and ankle stiffness.

Stand in a split stance with one foot forward and the other foot behind, holding the Viking press handle in front of your chest with both hands. Begin by lowering into a split squat, bending both knees until your back knee is just above the floor while keeping your chest upright. As you press through your front heel to return to the standing position, simultaneously press the Viking handle upwards and slightly forward, fully extending your arms. Bring the handle back to your chest as you lower into the next split squat. Ensure you maintain balance and stability throughout the movement by engaging your core.

Set two cable handles at chest height on opposite sides of a dual cable machine. Stand in the centre holding one handle in each hand. Pull the handles back and across your body in an “X” pattern, squeezing the shoulder blades together at the end range. Return slowly to the start with arms extended. Keep chest tall, core braced, and avoid shrugging the shoulders.

Set a cable pulley high and attach a rope handle. Kneel facing the machine, holding the rope just above your head with elbows bent. Brace your core and curl your torso downwards, bringing your elbows towards your knees while keeping hips still. Pause briefly at the bottom, then return to the starting position with control. Focus on using the abs to pull, not the arms or hips.

Stand tall holding a dumbbell in each hand at your sides, palms facing inward. With a slight bend in the elbows, raise the arms out to the sides until they reach shoulder height. Hold briefly at the top before lowering slowly under control. Maintain upright posture and avoid swinging. The emphasis is on pausing at peak contraction to build shoulder stability.

Sprint forward for 5 metres, then decelerate sharply to a complete stop on the spot. The moment balance is regained, re-accelerate immediately into another 5-metre sprint. Focus on crisp deceleration mechanics with hips low, chest forward and short, controlled braking steps - followed by an explosive first step out of the stop. Maintain posture and control in both the stop and the re-acceleration.

Set up in a push-up position with a low box placed just in front of your hands. Perform a powerful push-up, driving explosively through the arms to lift your hands off the ground. As you rise, place your hands on the box and absorb the landing by bending the elbows. Reset by stepping or jumping the hands back to the floor and repeat. Keep the core braced, body straight, and focus on speed and power in the push-off.

Stand tall with a slight forward lean, keeping your core engaged and ankles stiff. Rapidly lift and lower your knees just above shin height, maintaining quick, light foot contacts directly under your hips. Keep the movement fast and controlled, avoiding excessive vertical displacement.

Begin in a full plank position with hands under shoulders and feet hip-width apart. Keeping your hips stable and core braced, lift one hand to tap the opposite shoulder. Return it to the floor and repeat on the other side. Avoid rotating your hips or shifting your weight side-to-side. Keep the movement smooth and deliberate, maintaining a strong plank line throughout.

Stand tall next to a stable surface, such as a fence or pole, for balance. Shift your weight onto one leg and swing the opposite leg forward and backward in a controlled motion. Keep your torso upright, your core engaged, and avoid arching your back. Start with a small range of motion and gradually increase the height of the swing as your hip flexors and hamstrings loosen. Repeat all reps on one leg before switching to the other.

Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the ground, hip-width apart. Engage your core and press through your heels to lift your hips until your body forms a straight line from shoulders to knees. Hold the top position for 2-3 seconds, ensuring your glutes are fully engaged. Lower under control and repeat. Focus on squeezing your glutes at the top without overextending your lower back.

Begin in an athletic stance. Perform two powerful horizontal bounds from one leg to the other, covering distance with each stride. After the second bound, immediately transition into a short sprint of 5 to 10 metres. Focus on smooth transitions and aggressive acceleration out of the final bound. Stay low and drive forward during the sprint phase.

Set a line of low hurdles or cones in front of you. Step over each hurdle one at a time by lifting the lead knee high and driving it forward while keeping the torso upright. Clear the hurdle without rotating your hips or leaning to the side, then follow through with the trail leg in a smooth motion. Continue through the sequence with controlled and deliberate steps. Maintain balance and posture throughout. Without any equipment simply imagine hip-height hurdles to step over.

Overview: In this phase of your training, the primary focus is on enhancing acceleration and deceleration, primarily in the frontal plane. The training is designed to improve quickness when you drive past your man, as well as in powerfully cutting out towards space. There are three weekly sessions split between gym-based and pitch-based work. Session A is an additional daily prehab to stay fit with the regular 90 minutes incoming, while Sessions B and D  focus on acceleration and short-burst speed. Session C is gym-based with a focus on upper power and force production. Perform prehab on non-match or gym session days.

Notes:
Three sessions to complete weekly except on multiple match weeks.

** denotes raising to the greatest load possible while still moving at speed for the reps and sets scheme.

Exercise Description: Standing with your feet slightly outside of line with your shoulders in a very slight squat position. Hold the end of a barbell in both hands towards one side of your body. Lift upwards and over an imaginary fence in front of you to switch the barbell to the other side of your body. Twist your torso and hips with each repetition.

Anchor a resistance band low to the ground and loop it around the front of your ankle just below the joint line, pulling backward. Step the same foot forward into a half-kneeling or staggered stance so the band provides firm backward tension. From here, drive your knee slowly forward over the toes while keeping the heel pressed into the ground. Pause briefly at end range, then return under control. This encourages the tibia to glide properly over the ankle, improving dorsiflexion.

Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding the end of a landmine barbell in one hand at shoulder height. Dip slightly by bending knees and hips, then drive explosively upward, pressing the bar overhead while simultaneously splitting your legs into a lunge position (one foot forward, the other back). Lock the arm overhead and hold briefly, then bring the feet back together and lower the bar under control. Focus on speed, timing, and stability in the split stance.

Stand tall and lean forward gradually until your weight forces you to step out to avoid falling. As soon as the first step hits the ground, accelerate explosively into a 10-metre sprint. Keep your body at a strong forward lean through the first strides, driving knees and arms aggressively. Focus on smooth transition from the falling start into full sprint mechanics.

Stand tall with a slight forward lean, keeping your core engaged and ankles stiff. Rapidly tap the ground with quick, light contacts, bringing your knees only slightly above shin level. Keep your foot placement directly under your hips, maintaining a fast and controlled rhythm. Avoid excessive vertical movement and ensure a consistent turnover.
